conversation.message: School_E is my first-choice school, and I’m applying because I would commit to enrolling if accepted. I’m especially interested in School_E’s learning environment and community, and I’m ready to contribute actively to classes and school activities. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply immediately to my top-choice School_E. With identical priority rankings at all schools (A highest, E lowest), I have the weakest priority everywhere, so I should not waste time talking. I will make a clear, committed application emphasizing fit and that School_E is my first choice.

conversation.message: Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_E is your first choice. We appreciate your commitment and interest in our community. We are pleased to offer you admission—welcome to School_E.
conversation.thought: Student_E is applying to us as their first choice, which increases the likelihood of an immediate, binding match if we accept. However, on School_E’s true priority list, Student_E is ranked last (A > B > C > D > E). Given the market preferences, Student_A ranks School_E last and is unlikely to apply; Student_B ranks School_E 4th; Student_C ranks School_E last; Student_D ranks School_E last. Therefore, the probability that a higher-priority student (A–D) will apply to School_E in later rounds is low. With quota 1, accepting Student_E now secures a match and avoids ending unmatched while waiting for unlikely higher-priority applicants.

conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions team. I’m Student_C and School_C is my first-choice school. I’m very excited about the possibility of joining and would like to be considered for admission. Thank you for your time and consideration.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is School_C, and there is no prior history. With capacity 1 and identical priority orders across schools, applying immediately to my first choice maximizes my chance to secure the best possible match before seats fill.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your application and for naming School_C as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_C.

We look forward to having you join our community.

[ACTION] [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority ranks Student_A and Student_B above Student_C. However, in this round only Student_C has applied to me, and Student_C lists School_C as their first choice, making acceptance highly likely to finalize a match immediately. Student_A prefers School_B and School_A above School_C, and Student_B prefers School_A first; both may never apply to School_C. With quota 1, rejecting Student_C risks ending unmatched or settling for a lower-priority student later, while accepting secures a solid, willing match now.

conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions, I am Student_D. School_D is my first-choice school, and I am applying because I would be excited to enroll if admitted. I’m particularly drawn to School_D’s overall fit for my goals, and I’m ready to commit immediately if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_D, and all schools share the same priority order where I am ranked below A, B, and C. If I do not apply to my first choice immediately, I risk losing it to a higher-priority student who may also apply early. Therefore, I should apply to School_D in round 1 with a clear statement that it is my first choice and that I will commit if accepted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_D is your first choice. We appreciate your strong interest and commitment.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_D. Congratulations—we look forward to welcoming you.

[ACTION] [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: I have quota 1. My true priority ranks Student_D fourth (behind A, B, C). However, in this round only Student_D applied to me. Student_D lists School_D as first choice and is ready to commit, so accepting secures a match immediately. Waiting could allow higher-priority students (A/B/C) to apply later, but given their preferences (A prefers B>A>C>D; B prefers A>C>B>E>D; C prefers C>B>A>D), School_D is not their top choice and they may never reach me. With no competing applicants now and a credible commitment from Student_D, accepting maximizes certainty of filling my seat with an in-list student rather than risking ending unmatched.

conversation.message: Hello School_B Admissions Committee—I'm Student_A, and School_B is my first-choice school. I’m very excited about the opportunity to join and would enthusiastically accept an offer if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply immediately to my top-choice School_B. All schools share the same priority order with me (Student_A) ranked first, so an early [APPLY] to School_B should secure acceptance before any coordination issues arise.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_A,

Thank you for your application and for naming School_B as your first choice. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_B.

We look forward to welcoming you to our community.

Sincerely,
School_B Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_A is #1 on School_B's true priority list. They have applied directly to us in round 1 and explicitly state School_B is their first choice, so accepting now secures our top-ranked candidate and fills our single quota optimally. No higher-ranked alternative exists, and delaying risks losing Student_A to another school only if they were to change strategy; immediate acceptance maximizes our objective.

conversation.message: Dear School_A Admissions Committee, I’m Student_B and I’m formally applying to School_A as my top choice. I’m highly motivated by your academic rigor and would be ready to commit immediately if offered the seat. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is School_A, and all schools share the same priority order where I am ranked 2nd (after Student_A). In a capacity-1 setting, applying to my top choice immediately maximizes my chance to secure it before the seat is taken. I will make a clear, committed application and emphasize strong fit and readiness to enroll if accepted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your application and for naming School_A as your top choice. We appreciate your commitment and enthusiasm for our academic program.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_A. [ACCEPT]

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions
conversation.thought: School_A’s true priority ranks Student_A above Student_B. However, in round 1 the only applicant to School_A is Student_B, who also lists School_A as their top choice, making acceptance immediately secure. Waiting risks losing Student_B to another school in later rounds, and there is no guarantee Student_A will apply to School_A (Student_A prefers School_B first). With quota 1, accepting Student_B now yields a solid match with a highly-ranked (2nd) student rather than gambling for Student_A.
